subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test error handling?
msgSnippet: Let me give a more concrete example. try { // execute my sql query ResultSet rs = sql.executeQuery(); while (rs.next()) { String name = rs.getString( name );
messageBody:
Let me give a more concrete example.

try {
// execute my sql query
ResultSet rs = sql.executeQuery();
while (rs.next()) {
String name = rs.getString("name");
// do my processing
}
sql.close();
}
catch (SQLException e) {
// do my smart error handling here.
//
// however this is never called because it is hard to
// generate a SQLException.
}


I may simulate the error condition by throwing my own SQLException, such as
adding some

if (testExceptionFlag)
throw new SQLException("test the error handler");

But this would add clutter to the code. Mock object seems cleaner. However,
ResultSet is a large interface to implement. Also the ResultSet object used is
not created by me but by .executeQuery() so I have no control on what object it
creates.

I hope I can my some tips to exercise the error handler. But I want to avoid
heavily instrument the code.

Wai Yip Tung





--- "Dave Astels <dave@...>" <dave@...> wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
>
> > You need to force an object to throw the particular SQLException you
> > want to throw into the object that is supposed to handle it. Without
> > knowing what those objects are, I can't write a better description of
> > the solution.
>
> Mock as be used for this. If you can mock the object that can throw
> the exception, you can configurate to just throw it when called. Then
> you can test that the exception was handled correctly.
>
> Dave
